Headline.Para: Shareholders give thumbs up to Ezion debt plan

LeadPara.Para: Group still faces arduous journey to recovery; it will take steps to stave off cash burn from non-productive assets: CFO

TailParas.Para: OFFSHORE and marine group Ezion Holdings on Wednesday won a majority vote of over 99 per cent from its shareholders in support of a landmark debt refinancing plan touted as having tabled no haircuts for its debt-holders.
Shareholders representing in excess of 799.2 million shares, or 99.22 per cent of the votes cast, voted in favour of the plan.
When fully executed, the plan that seeks deleveraging from swapping debt to equity calls for significant dilution of existing equity.

Holders of S$575 million in securities will hold 35 per cent of the enlarged equity if they fully exercise the debt-to-equity swap options and their warrants. Existing shareholders can retain 56 per cent of the enlarged equity on exercising all the warrants allotted. Bank lenders and other stakeholders stand to hold up to another 9 per cent.
The plan will also see new shares and option shares issued as settlement of professional fees and an incoming investor, Asdew Acquisitions Pte Ltd.

Shareholders have granted Ezion approval to proceed with the debt plan despite being forewarned last week of a massive loss after US$900 million of impairments. Ezion widened its net loss to US$1.02 billion for the year ended Dec 31, 2017, compared to US$33.61 million for FY16. Coming on the heels of a series of bad news in this prolonged O&M downturn, group chief financial officer Paul Goon told The Business Times that he is both "thankful and humbled by" the almost unanimous shareholders' support.

But Mr Goon said that Ezion has stood out from other debt-laden O&M players for having continued to generate positive cash flows primarily on the resilient demand for its liftboats. The group's net operating cash flow was US$25 million for the fourth quarter and US$65 million for FY17.

The group has thus far opted against tabling direct haircuts for its security holders and bank lenders. Instead, it has sought to deleverage by offering debt-to-equity swaps to security holders while pushing out most principal repayments for its bank loans to six years from now.

Mr Goon acknowledged, however, that Ezion still faces an arduous journey ahead. Business fundamentals "won't fly" this year though they are expected to improve from year-end through to the next financial year.

But Ezion is taking steps to stave off cash burn from non-productive assets. For a start, it is looking to divest about half of the combined 65-strong fleet of service rigs, offshore support vessels and barges that are facing difficulty in getting work. The group will thereafter rely mainly on its 14 liftboats for revenue generation.

Mr Goon said that post-debt refinancing, the group hopes to bring in strategic investors that will augment the equity and cash available to grow to a target fleet size of 20 to 25 liftboats in the next six years.
Ezion needs fresh equity injection in order to grow its business because it will still have to prioritise a sizeable chunk of any spare cash available for the repayment of bank debts.
This was part of the understanding reached with bank lenders - that excess cash after meeting operating expenditure, working capital needs and target reserves will go towards paying down bank loans.

The group has projected some US$900 million in total operating cash flows for the next six years. Divestments of non-core asset holdings, including six offshore support vessels co-owned with Ezra Holdings and service rigs previously owned through a joint venture with Swissco Holdings, are also on the table and these will help bolster cash flows.
Mr Goon expressed confidence that in the next six years, the group stands to pare down by half its current senior loans now totalling some US$1.5 billion.
